snippet: When Edward J. Snowden worked as a C.I.A. technician in 2009, he was suspected of trying to break into classified files, but a report was never forwarded when he left to become an N.S.A. contractor, officials said.
abstract: Senior American officials report that when Edward J Snowden worked as a Central Intelligence Agency technician in 2009, he was suspected of trying to break into classified computer files; report of his supervisor's cautionary note and of CIA's suspicions was never forwarded, however, when he left to become a National Security Agency contractor.

byline.contributor: Michael S. Schmidt contributed reporting from Washington, and Andrew Roth from Moscow.

lead_paragraph: When Edward J. Snowden worked as a C.I.A. technician in 2009, he was suspected of trying to break into classified files, but a report was never forwarded when he left to become an N.S.A. contractor, officials said.

headline.main: C.I.A. Warning on Snowden in ’09 Said to Slip Through the Cracks
headline.print_headline: C.I.A. Noted Its Suspicions Over Snowden
